title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 15 march [1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 15 March [1869]
text: 15 March 1869My dear Waltdontdon't be frightened at getting this unseasonable letter there is nothing more than usual the matter i am quite lame but otherwise as well as usual i hope this will find you over your trouble with the distress in your head) the cause of my writing georgeGeorge has got disappointed and dontdon't hardly know what to doodo in the money matters the masons he contracted to doodo the work lumped out the plaisteringplastering and they have got it all done but the last coat and smith says they wontwon't finish it till they have the payment which is six hundred dollars he wants to know if you could without trouble let him have it he says he could pay you back in mayMay certainly he has tried every way that could be thought of smith had a man to day to look at his house he would sell it 500 dolldollars less than his price if he could raise some money on it but the man dident buy it) georgGeorge says if it would be marchMarch 15 a trouble for you to get it he will doodo the best he can but if you could send him a draft for five or six hundred it would accomadateaccommodate him very much indeed he wants you to telegraph to him when you get this letter as he expects he will have to go to the foundry this week he says if it wasentwasn't for our moving and his letting out the lower part he woulentwouldn't care if it did stop he feels shuresure of getting money by the first of may he has tried to transfer the mortgage on this house offered the back interest and more besides but it all failed i dontdon't suppose there hardly ever was such difficulydifficulty the real estate agent say it will be very different in a little while) georgeGeorge says this building without money is a bad business i suppose walterWalter deadear you got my letter of last week) there is 800 dollars to come from jeffJeff yet but he cantcan't pay but 200 dollar a month) the houses is both insured) if you cantcan't send it waltWalt without difficulty georgeGeorge wontwon't think hard i told him if you could i knew you would)no mormore but rememremember youyour motherLW Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 15 March [1869]
